title: Architecture, Design and Planning Dean's International Merit Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Sydney School of Architecture Design and Planning
description:
The Architecture, Design and Planning Dean's International Merit Scholarship is aimed at encouraging talented international students to pursue undergraduate study at the Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning. Established in 2003, this scholarship is valued at $1000 and is tenable for one year only. Eligible candidates must be international students who have recently completed high school, applying for specific degree programs, and must have a minimum ATAR of 95 or equivalent. No application is required as eligible candidates will be considered automatically as part of the admissions process. 1. Background
a. Established in 2003 by the Dean, this Scholarship aims to encourage the most talented individuals to undertake undergraduate courses in the Faculty of Architecture, Design and Planning.
2. Eligibility
a. Open to international students who are recent school leavers and that apply and enrol in either of one of the following degree programs administered by the Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning at the University of Sydney:
I. Bachelor of Architecture and Environments,
II. Bachelor of Design in Architecture,
III. Bachelor of Design in Architecture (Honours) and Master of Architecture,
IV. Bachelor of Design (Interaction Design), or
V. Bachelor of Design (Interaction Design) and Bachelor of Advanced Studies.
b. Eligible students must have achieved a minimum ATAR equivalent of 95 and must not have completed any prior tertiary studies.
3. Selection Criteria
a. The Scholarship will be awarded on the basis of academic merit as demonstrated through the HSC equivalent.
b. The Scholarship will be awarded on the nomination of the Dean and Head of School of the Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning.
4. Value
a. The Scholarship is valued at $1,000 and is tenable for one year only.
b. The Scholarship value will be paid as a lump sum payment after the first applicable census date.
c. Deferral of the Scholarship is not permitted without the prior permission of the Dean and Head of School and it is not transferable to another University school, faculty or university.
d. The Scholarship will be offered subject to the availability of funds.
e. No other amount is payable.
5. Ongoing eligibility
a. The recipient must remain successfully enrolled in their degree for one year.
6. Termination
a. The Scholarship will be terminated if the recipient:
I. withdraws from an eligible course or fails to enrol,
II. no longer is enrolled as an international student,
III. does not maintain satisfactory academic performance,
IV. is determined by the University to be guilty of serious misconduct, including, but not limited to, having provided false or misleading information as part of their Scholarship application,
V. does not resume study at the end of a period of approved leave, or
VI. any other provision as indicated in these terms that would lead to termination.
b. Once the Scholarship has been terminated, it will not be reinstated unless due to University error.
c. Where a student is found guilty of serious misconduct or withdraws from the relevant course, the University reserves the right to request that any Scholarship funds paid to the Scholarship recipient be reimbursed.

degree_programs: Bachelor of Design in Architecture (Honours) and Master of Architecture
Bachelor of Design (Interaction Design) and Bachelor of Advanced Studies
education_criteria.prior_studies: Must not have completed any prior tertiary studies

achievement_criteria.academic_merit: Awarded on the basis of academic merit as demonstrated through the HSC equivalent

title: Diana Inglis Carment Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Sydney School of Architecture Design and Planning
description:
The Diana Inglis Carment Scholarship is an undergraduate scholarship for honours level students at the University of Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning. Valued at $5,000, it supports students pursuing honours studies in the Bachelor of Design in Architecture (Honours) degree. Established in 2007 through a gift from the family of the late Diana Inglis Carment, the scholarship aims to assist students in their academic pursuits. Eligibility requires an unconditional offer of admission for the honours degree and full-time enrolment in the semester following the award. 1. Background
a. This Scholarship was established in 2007 with a gift of $100,000 from the family of the late Diana Inglis Carment, to provide assistance to students studying Honours in the University of Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning.
2. Eligibility
a. Applicants must have completed requirements for the Bachelor of Design in Architecture at the University of Sydney, or an equivalent degree at another University, and have an unconditional offer of admission for, or be commencing, the Bachelor of Design in Architecture (Honours) degree within the University of Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning. 
b. Applicants must be enrolling full-time in the semester immediately following award of this scholarship.
3. Selection Criteria
a. The Scholarship will be awarded on the basis of:
I. academic merit,
II. research proposal, and
III. a personal statement which outlines how the Scholarship will assist the applicant with their studies. 
b. The Scholarship will be awarded on the nomination of the Honours Year Program Director, University of Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning, or their nominated delegates. 
4. Value
a. The Scholarship is valued at $5,000 and is tenable for one year. 
b. The scholarship value will be paid as a single payment after the census date of the first semester of enrolment in the relevant course. 
c. Deferral of the Scholarship is not permitted, and it is not transferable to another University school, faculty or university. 
d. The Scholarship will be offered subject to the availability of funds.
e. No other amount is payable.
5. Ongoing eligibility
a. None apply.
6. Termination
a. The Scholarship will be terminated if the recipient:
I. withdraws from an eligible course or fails to enrol,
II. commences part-time study without prior approval,
III. does not maintain satisfactory academic performance,
IV. is determined by the University to be guilty of serious misconduct, including, but not limited to, having provided false or misleading information as part of their Scholarship application,
V. does not resume study at the end of a period of approved leave, or
VI. any other provision as indicated in these terms that would lead to termination.
b. Once the Scholarship has been terminated, it will not be reinstated unless due to University error.
c. Where a student is found guilty of serious misconduct or the Scholarship is terminated under any instance in the Termination Clause of these terms and conditions, the University reserves the right to request that any Scholarship funds paid to the Scholarship recipient be reimbursed.
education_criteria: Applicants must have completed requirements for the Bachelor of Design in Architecture at the University of Sydney, or an equivalent degree at another University, and have an unconditional offer of admission for, or be commencing, the Bachelor of Design in Architecture (Honours) degree within the University of Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning.
experience_criteria: Applicants must be enrolling full-time in the semester immediately following award of this scholarship.
research_criteria: The Scholarship will be awarded on the basis of academic merit, research proposal, and a personal statement which outlines how the Scholarship will assist the applicant with their studies.

title: Margot and Neville Gruzman Award for Urban Design in Architecture
provider: University of Sydney - Sydney School of Architecture Design and Planning
description:
The Margot and Neville Gruzman Award for Urban Design in Architecture is a scholarship aimed at providing assistance to students studying Urban Design at the University of Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning. It is valued at $2,500 and is awarded to students currently enrolled in the final year of the Bachelor of Architecture and Environments who have successfully completed the Unit of Study BAEN3001: Design Integration Lab: Urban in the current academic year. No application is required; eligible students will be automatically considered based on their academic merit in the specified unit. 1. Background
a. This Scholarship was established to provide assist to students studying Urban Design at the University of Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning.
b. This Scholarship has been donated by Neville Gruzman.
2. Eligibility
a. Applicants must be currently enrolled in the final year of Bachelor of Architecture and Environments at the Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning.
b. Applicants must have successfully completed the Unit of Study BAEN3001: Design Integration Lab: Urban, in the current academic year.
3. Selection Criteria
a. The Scholarship will be awarded on the basis of academic merit based on the applicant’s final result in BAEN3001: Design Integration Lab: Urban.
b. The Scholarship will be awarded by the Head of School and Dean of the Sydney School of Architecture, Design and planning, or their nominated delegates. 
4. Value
a. The Scholarship is valued at $2,500 and will be paid as a one-off payment on receipt of the Scholarship Acceptance form.
b. Deferral and/or suspension of the Scholarship is not permitted without the prior permission of the Head of School and Dean of the Sydney School of Architecture, Design and planning, or their nominated delegates, and it is not transferable to another University school, faculty or university without prior approval.
c. The Scholarship will be offered subject to the availability of funds.
d. No other amount is payable.
5. Ongoing Eligibility
a. None apply.
6. Termination
a. The Scholarship will be terminated if the recipient:
I. withdraws from an eligible course or fails to enrol,
II. commences part-time study, 
III. does not maintain satisfactory academic performance, or
IV. is determined by the University to be guilty of serious misconduct, including, but not limited to, having provided false or misleading information as part of their Scholarship application.
b. Once the Scholarship has been terminated, it will not be reinstated unless due to University error.  

c. Where a student is found guilty of serious misconduct or the Scholarship is terminated under any instance in the Termination Clause of these terms and conditions, the University reserves the right to request that any Scholarship funds paid to the Scholarship recipient be reimbursed.

education_criteria.academic_requirements: Must be currently enrolled in the final year and have successfully completed the Unit of Study BAEN3001: Design Integration Lab: Urban, in the current academic year.

title: Lendlease Bradfield Urbanisation Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
major: Urbanism related fields (e.g., urban development, urban planning, urban design, urban/social policy, project finance, project and/or facilities management, transport logistics and engineering)
description:
The Lendlease Bradfield Urbanisation Scholarship is an undergraduate coursework scholarship generously donated by Lendlease in honour of John Bradfield. It aims to develop the potential of students and nurture Sydney visionaries who aspire to shape the city's future. The scholarship is valued at $10,000 per year for the full-time duration of the recipient’s undergraduate program, including combined degree programs. It is awarded based on academic merit and a response to an essay question, with a minimum Weighted Average Mark (WAM) of 65 required for eligibility. The scholarship will be paid in two equal instalments after the census date of each semester. 1. Background
a. The Scholarship was generously donated by Lendlease and established in honour of John Bradfield who played a monumental part in shaping Sydney. The Scholarship aims to develop the potential of students and nurture Sydney visionaries who aspire to shape the city's future.
2. Eligibility
a. Applicants must be enrolled in an undergraduate degree in one of the following four faculties/University schools at the University of Sydney:
I. Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences,
II. Faculty of Engineering,
III. Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning, and
IV. University of Sydney Business School.
b. Applicants must be undertaking studies within one of the above listed faculties/University schools that is related to urbanism including without limitation, urban development, urban planning, urban design, urban/social policy, project finance, project and/or facilities management, transport logistics and engineering.
c. Applicants must be enrolled in either their first or second year of studies and have a minimum Weighted Average Mark (WAM) of 65.
d. Applicants cannot have studied more than 96 credit points in their degree program (including degree combined programs).
3. Selection Criteria
a. The Scholarship will be awarded on the basis of:
I. academic merit, and
II. response to the advertised essay question.
b. Shortlisted applicants will need to make a 5 minute presentation using visual aids.
c. Applications will be shortlisted by University of Sydney academic staff representing each of the above listed faculties/University schools. The final selection committee will consist of the same academic staff, and up to two representatives from Lendlease. The final decision rests with the University.
d. In acknowledgment of the Donor's intention to promote gender equality, the University will endeavour to award no less than 50% of the scholarships in each ten year period to female applicants.
4. Value
a. The Scholarship is valued at $10,000 per annum and is tenable for the full-time duration of the recipient’s undergraduate program including combined degree programs.
b. The Scholarship annual value will be paid in two equal instalments after the census date of each semester.
c. Where a recipient has been permitted to study part-time, the amount awarded for each relevant semester will be half the full-time rate.
d. Deferral of the Scholarship is not permitted without the prior permission of Head of Scholarships and it is not transferable to another University school, faculty or university.
e. The Scholarship will be offered subject to the availability of funds.
f. No other amount is payable.
5. Ongoing eligibility
a. To continue receipt of the Scholarship, the recipient must maintain a minimum Semester Average Mark (SAM) of 65 each semester and remain enrolled full-time in their eligible course.
b. Recipients may request to study part-time, where they can demonstrate circumstances that impact their ability to successfully undertake full-time studies. Examples include a medical condition, or other significant hardship. Request must be approved by the Head of Scholarships prior to the commencement of part-time study.
c. Recipients undertaking an exchange during the tenure of this Scholarship are required to have achieved a Satisfied Requirements grade (SR) to receive their next payment.
6. Termination
a. The Scholarship will be terminated if the recipient:
I. withdraws from an eligible course, faculty/University school, or fails to enrol,
II. withdraws from studies related to urbanism,
III. commences part-time study without prior approval,
IV. does not maintain satisfactory academic performance,
V. is determined by the University to be guilty of serious misconduct, including, but not limited to, having provided false or misleading information as part of their Scholarship application,
VI. is awarded an alternative primary scholarship valued at $8,000 per annum or more that provides a living allowance. In such circumstances this scholarship will be terminated in favour of the alternative scholarship for the same purpose where the alternative scholarship is of higher value,
VII. does not resume study at the end of a period of approved leave, or
VIII. any other provision as indicated in these terms that would lead to termination. 
b. Once the Scholarship has been terminated, it will not be reinstated unless due to University error.
c. Where a student is found guilty of serious misconduct or withdraws from the relevant course, the University reserves the right to request that any Scholarship funds paid to the Scholarship recipient be reimbursed.
7. Other requirements
a. The recipient may be invited to be an ambassador for the Lendlease Bradfield Urbanisation Scholarship and the University of Sydney.

title: Garton Scholarship No II for French
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
description:
The Garton Scholarship No II for French is an undergraduate scholarship for third year Arts and Social Sciences students studying French. Valued at $5,000 for one year, it is awarded based on academic merit to the student with the highest average mark in FRNC3633 and another 6 credit points at either FRNC2000 or FRNC3000 level in the second year of the applicable degree. No separate application is required for this scholarship, and recipients must maintain a minimum Semester Average Mark (SAM) of 65 each semester. 1. Background
a. This Scholarship was founded in 1898 from a bequest from Thomas Garton of Clapham, London. The purpose of the Scholarship is to provide financial assistance to an undergraduate student studying in their third year of the advanced stream in French.
2. Eligibility
a. The Scholarship is offered subject to the applicant being currently enrolled full-time in their third year of an undergraduate degree within the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences at the University of Sydney.
b. Applicants must be enrolled in FRNC3634 and another 6 credit points of FRNC3000 level units.
c. No separate application is required for this Scholarship.
3. Selection Criteria
a. The Scholarship will be awarded on the basis of academic merit to the student with the highest average mark in FRNC3633 and another 6 credit points at either FRNC2000 or FRNC3000 level in the second year of the applicable degree.
b. The Scholarship will be awarded by the Head of School of the School of Languages and Cultures, or their nominated delegate.
4. Value
a. The Scholarship is valued at $5,000 per annum and is tenable for 1 year.
b. The Scholarship annual value will be paid in two equal instalments after the census date of each semester.
c. Deferral of the Scholarship is not permitted without the prior permission of the Head of School and it is not transferable to another University school, faculty or university without prior approval.
d. The Scholarship will be offered subject to the availability of funds.
e. No other amount is payable.
5. Ongoing eligibility
a. To continue receipt of the Scholarship, the recipient must maintain a minimum Semester Average Mark (SAM) of 65 each semester.
b. Recipients undertaking an exchange during the tenure of this Scholarship are required to have achieved a Satisfied Requirements grade (SR) to receive their next payment.
6. Termination
a. The Scholarship will be terminated if the recipient:
I. withdraws from an eligible course or fails to enrol,
II. commences part-time study without prior approval,

III. does not maintain satisfactory academic performance,

IV. is determined by the University to be guilty of serious misconduct, including, but not limited to, having provided false or misleading information as part of their Scholarship application, or

V. does not resume study at the end of a period of approved leave.

b. Once the Scholarship has been terminated, it will not be reinstated unless due to University error.

c. Where a student is found guilty of serious misconduct or the Scholarship is terminated under any instance in the Termination Clause of these terms and conditions, the University reserves the right to request that any Scholarship funds paid to the Scholarship recipient be reimbursed.

title: The Thomas Henry Coulson Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
description:
The Thomas Henry Coulson Scholarship provides support to undergraduate students studying English who are experiencing disadvantage or hardship. Established in 2020, this scholarship is funded by a donation made in 1916 from Miss Mary Jane Coulson in memory of her brother. The scholarship is available to students enrolled in their second, third, or fourth year within the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences, and applicants must demonstrate financial hardship based on specific criteria. A successful recipient enrolled full-time will receive $5,500 for up to one year, while part-time recipients will receive 50% of the full-time rate for up to two years, subject to satisfactory academic performance. 1. Background
a. This Scholarship was established in 2020 to provide support to undergraduate students studying English who are experiencing disadvantage or hardship.
b. This Scholarship is funded by a donation made in 1916 from Miss Mary Jane Coulson in memory of her brother.
2. Eligibility
a. The Scholarship is offered subject to the applicant being currently enrolled in their second, third of fourth year in an undergraduate degree majoring in English within the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences at the University of Sydney.
b. Applicants must demonstrate financial hardship based on one or more of the below:
I. identify as an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Island person as defined in the University of Sydney’s Confirmation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Identity Policy 2015,
II. low socio-economic status,
III. carer responsibilities,
IV. long-term medical condition/disability (including ongoing effects of abuse),
V. sole-parent responsibilities,
VI. regional or remote disadvantage,
VII. refugee status,
VIII. LGBTIQ+, and/or
IX. first in family.
3. Selection Criteria
a. The Scholarship will be awarded on the basis of:
I. academic merit, and
II. a personal statement that demonstrates:
i. why they are studying English,
ii. a commitment to studying English, and
iii. the impact their financial hardship has on their studies.
b. The Scholarship will be awarded by a selection committee consisting of the:
I. Chair of Discipline, and 
II. their nominated delegates.
4. Value
a. A recipient enrolled full-time will receive $5,500 per annum for up to one year, subject to satisfactory academic performance.
b. A recipient enrolled part-time will receive 50% of the full-time rate for up to 2 years, subject to satisfactory academic performance.
c. The Scholarship annual value will be paid in two equal instalments after the census date of each semester.
d. Deferral and suspension of the Scholarship is not permitted without the prior permission of the Head of School, School of Art, Communication and English.
e. The scholarship cannot be transferred to another University school, faculty or university.
f. The Scholarship will be offered subject to the availability of funds.
g. No other amount is payable.
5. Ongoing eligibility
a. To continue receipt of the Scholarship, the recipient must maintain a minimum Semester Average Mark (SAM) of 50 each semester.
b. Recipients undertaking an exchange during the tenure of this Scholarship are required to have achieved a Satisfied Requirements grade (SR) to receive their next payment.
6. Termination
a. The Scholarship will be terminated if the recipient:
I. withdraws from an eligible course or fails to enrol,
II. does not maintain satisfactory academic performance,
III. is determined by the University to be guilty of serious misconduct, including, but not limited to, having provided false or misleading information as part of their Scholarship application, or
IV. does not resume study at the end of a period of approved leave.
b. Once the Scholarship has been terminated, it will not be reinstated unless due to University error.

c. Where a student is found guilty of serious misconduct or the Scholarship is terminated under any instance in the Termination Clause of these terms and conditions, the University reserves the right to request that any Scholarship funds paid to the Scholarship recipient be reimbursed.

title: SCA Student Fauvette Loureiro Memorial Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
degree_level: Please refer to the original url for more details.
description:
The Fauvette Loureiro Memorial Scholarship aims to support Sydney College of Arts (SCA) graduates to pursue a program of professional development through travel. The scholarship is valued at $10,000 for a successful emerging recipient and $30,000 for a successful mid-career/established recipient. Each shortlisted applicant will receive $1,000 to assist with costs associated with their participation in the accompanying Fauvette Loureiro Memorial Scholarship Exhibition. Applicants must have graduated from SCA with a ‘conferred’ or ‘awarded’ graduation status and meet specific eligibility criteria. 1. Background
a. This Scholarship established in 1997 through a gift from the estate of Renee Fauvette Erdos, an educator and founder of the History Teachers' Association of NSW; celebrating the memory of her mother Fauvette Loureiro.
b. The purpose of the scholarship is to support graduates of the Sydney College of Arts (SCA) to pursue a program of professional development through travel.
2. Eligibility
a. Applicants must have graduated from the Sydney College of the Arts at the University of Sydney prior to submitting their application. The graduation status of the applicant must be ‘awarded’ or ‘conferred.’
b. Applicants must be willing and able to undertake the program/project which is to be completed by the end of the following year after receipt of the scholarship.
c. Applicants must define their entry to the emerging and mid-career/established categories as below:

I. Emerging:
i. applicants must be five years or less from graduation from their most recent course of study at the SCA, or
ii. applicants who have graduated from their most recent course of study at the SCA more than five years ago but self-identify as being an emerging practitioner, must provide a justification.
II. Mid-career/established:
i. applicants must be more than 5 years from graduation from their most recent course of study at the SCA, or
ii. applicants who have graduated from their most recent course of study at the SCA five years or less ago but self-identify as being a mid- career/established practitioner, must provide a justification.
d. Applicants who meet any of the below criteria are ineligible to apply:
I. Currently enrolled in an undergraduate or postgraduate program of study at the Sydney College of the Arts.

II. Deferred a degree program at Sydney College of the Arts in order to travel.
III. Research students who have the current degree status of ‘under examination’.
IV. Have been the recipient of this scholarship in the previous five years.
V. Have already commenced the program/project for which they are applying.
VI. Are continuing employees at the Sydney College of the Arts.
3. Shortlisted Applicants
a. Applicants must be available to contribute an artwork(s) to the accompanying Fauvette Loureiro Memorial Scholarship exhibition at the SCA Gallery.
4. Selection Criteria
a. The Scholarship will be awarded on the basis of:
I. the artistic and/or academic merit,

II. previous work and/or exhibitions,
III. work exhibited in the finalist exhibition,
IV. project/program description,
V. budget, and
VI. curriculum vitae.
b. Applicants who are completing projects working with Indigenous communities must also provide confirmed letters of support and/or involvement.
c. Applicants will be firstly shortlisted, and the final Scholarship will be awarded by a selection committee consisting of:
I. The Sydney College of the Arts Director, or their nominated delegate,

II. a practicing professional artist, and
III. a recognised art critic, gallery director, arts worker, curator or member of an established arts and cultural organisation external to the University of Sydney.
5. Value
a. Each shortlisted applicant will be provided with $1,000 to assist with the costs associated with their participation in the accompanying Fauvette Loureiro Memorial Scholarship Exhibition.
b. The successful emerging scholarship recipient will receive $10,000.
c. The successful mid-career/established scholarship recipient will receive $30,000.
d. The successful applicants will be required to reconfirm their budgets prior to the scholarship payment. The successful applicants will be paid the scholarship in one instalment on acceptance of the final budget/program.
e. Deferral of the Scholarship is not permitted.
f. The Scholarship will be offered subject to the availability of funds.
g. No other amount is payable.
6. Ongoing eligibility
a. To continue receipt of the Scholarship, the recipient must conduct their travel and project as proposed in their application.
7. Termination
a. The Scholarship will be terminated if the recipient:
I. does not conduct or withdraws from their travel and project as outlined in their application,

II. is determined by the University to be guilty of serious misconduct, including, but not limited to, having provided false or misleading information as part of their Scholarship application,
III. any other provision as indicated in these terms that would lead to termination.
b. Once the Scholarship has been terminated, it will not be reinstated unless due to University error.
c. Where the recipient is found guilty of serious misconduct or withdraws from the relevant travel and project, the University reserves the right to request that any Scholarship funds paid to the Scholarship recipient be reimbursed.
8. Reporting
a. A one-to-two-page report on the activities undertaken through the scholarship is required on completion of the awarded program/project.
b. Reports must be e-mailed to sca.enquiries@sydney.edu.au

description: This scholarship has been established for allied health students by the University of Sydney and the Cerebral Palsy Alliance. The scholarship is funded by a bequest from Professor Cowan and supports students in occupational therapy, speech pathology, or physiotherapy who demonstrate interest in disability and pediatrics and are available to undertake a practicum with the Cerebral Palsy Alliance.

education_criteria.educational_background: Must have an unconditional offer of admission or be currently enrolled in an undergraduate degree at the University of Sydney

personal_criteria.nationality: Must identify as an Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander person
personal_criteria.personal_background: Must identify as an Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander person as defined in the University of Sydney’s Confirmation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Identity Policy 2015

achievement_criteria.community_service: Preference will be given to applicants who can demonstrate financial hardship

title: Chancellor's Award
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty scholarships
description: A $10,000 scholarship awarded to school-leavers with an outstanding performance in the NSW Higher School Certificate Examination (ATAR 99.90) or equivalent. Recipients must be current school leavers, have a University of Sydney course on their UAC application preferences, and be domestic students (including citizens of New Zealand applying through UAC).

education_criteria.specific_degree: Undergraduate degree or combined undergraduate degree
education_criteria.educational_background: Current school leavers

personal_criteria.nationality: Australian citizen, permanent resident, or citizen of New Zealand

achievement_criteria.awards: Outstanding performance in the NSW Higher School Certificate Examination

title: David Clarke Memorial Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty scholarships
description: This scholarship was established in 2011 to provide assistance to applicants who demonstrate outstanding academic achievement and potential, and who are Sydney University rugby players with ambitions for higher achievements in the sport of rugby. Applicants must be enrolled full-time, have completed at least 48 credit points, and be citizens of Australia, New Zealand or Australian Permanent Residents.

education_criteria.educational_background: Completed at least 48 credit points in the degree

personal_criteria.nationality: Australian citizen, New Zealand citizen, or Australian Permanent Resident
personal_criteria.citizenship: Australian citizen, New Zealand citizen, or Australian Permanent Resident

experience_criteria.specific_skills_or_abilities: Demonstrated embodiment of values and high standards of integrity

title: Dialysis Australia Nursing Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney Susan Wakil School of Nursing and Midwifery
funding_level: $32,500 per annum for up to 3 years
description: This scholarship was established in 2023 to provide assistance to students studying an undergraduate degree within the University of Sydney Susan Wakil School of Nursing and Midwifery who can demonstrate financial need or financial or social disadvantage.

education_criteria.institution: University of Sydney Susan Wakil School of Nursing and Midwifery
education_criteria.minimum_GPA: Minimum Semester Average Mark (SAM) of 50 each semester

personal_criteria.financial_need: Must demonstrate financial need or disadvantage
personal_criteria.socioeconomic_status: Must be from a low socio-economic area

title: Digital Health Internship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty scholarships
description: The scholarship is funded by the Digital Health Cooperative Research Centre (DHCRC) and supports students currently enrolled in a coursework degree at the University of Sydney to complete an internship in digital health.
education_criteria: Currently enrolled in a coursework degree at the University of Sydney at the time of application.
experience_criteria: Must complete an internship in digital health.

title: Dr Hooi Chew Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty scholarships
description: Established in 2024, this Scholarship has been generously funded by Dr Hooi Chew to support students from rural or regional Australia in the Faculty of Engineering at the University of Sydney, who are experiencing financial hardship.
education_criteria: Not specified

title: Ernest Heine Family Foundation Digital Music Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty scholarships
description: Established in 2023, the Ernest Heine Family Foundation Digital Music Scholarship supports undergraduate students to study digital music at the Sydney Conservatorium of Music at the University of Sydney. Applicants must have an unconditional offer of a Bachelor of Music at the Sydney Conservatorium of Music and study in the Digital Music and Media Program.

education_criteria.educational_background: unconditional offer of a Bachelor of Music at the Sydney Conservatorium of Music

title: George Harris Scholarship in Chemistry Honours
provider: School of Chemistry at the University of Sydney
description: Established in 2023, this scholarship is supported by a generous donation from George Harris to encourage new discoveries in Chemistry. This scholarship supports students undertaking an Honours program in the School of Chemistry at the University of Sydney, with preference for Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander students or those experiencing financial hardship or other disadvantages.
education_criteria: Not specified

title: JACE Foundation Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty scholarships
description: The purpose of the JACE Foundation Scholarship is to support students with Autism Spectrum Disorder by facilitating and supporting their participation in University of Sydney courses. Applicants must be formally diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder, registered with the Inclusion and Disability Services (IDS), and able to demonstrate financial hardship.

education_criteria.minimum_GPA: minimum Semester Average Mark (SAM) of 50 each semester
education_criteria.enrollment_status: unconditional offer of admission or currently enrolled

personal_criteria.personal_background: formally diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder

achievement_criteria.other_achievements: evidence of financial need or disadvantage, academic merit

title: Judge Ralph J Perdriau Practical Legal Training Scholarship for Redfern Legal Centre
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty scholarships
description: Established by a bequest, this Scholarship is in memory of alumnus Judge Ralph J Perdriau (LLB 1919) who drafted the Workers' Compensation Bill in 1925. The scholarship supports students undertaking practical legal training in employment and discrimination law at the Redfern Legal Centre.

education_criteria.specific_degree: Bachelor of Laws (LLB) or Juris Doctor (JD)
education_criteria.educational_background: Currently enrolled in final semester

personal_criteria.personal_background: Preference may be given to applicants who identify as an Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander person

experience_criteria.specific_skills_or_abilities: Commitment to social justice and ability to work with people experiencing disadvantage

certification_criteria.specialized_qualifications: Must satisfy the eligibility requirements for PLT outlined by the Legal Professional Admission Board

title: Architecture, Design and Planning Dean's International Merit Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Sydney School of Architecture Design and Planning
description: The Architecture, Design and Planning Dean's International Merit Scholarship aims to encourage talented international students to pursue undergraduate study at the Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning. Eligible candidates must be international students who have recently completed high school with a minimum ATAR of 95 or equivalent.

degree_programs: Bachelor of Design in Architecture (Honours) and Master of Architecture
Bachelor of Design (Interaction Design) and Bachelor of Advanced Studies
education_criteria.prior_studies: Must not have completed any prior tertiary studies

achievement_criteria.academic_merit: Awarded on the basis of academic merit as demonstrated through the HSC equivalent

title: Diana Inglis Carment Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Sydney School of Architecture Design and Planning
description: The Diana Inglis Carment Scholarship supports honours level students at the University of Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning. Established in 2007 through a gift from the family of the late Diana Inglis Carment, the scholarship assists students in their academic pursuits in the Bachelor of Design in Architecture (Honours) degree.
education_criteria: Applicants must have completed requirements for the Bachelor of Design in Architecture at the University of Sydney, or an equivalent degree at another University, and have an unconditional offer of admission for, or be commencing, the Bachelor of Design in Architecture (Honours) degree within the University of Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning.
experience_criteria: Applicants must be enrolling full-time in the semester immediately following award of this scholarship.
research_criteria: The Scholarship will be awarded on the basis of academic merit, research proposal, and a personal statement which outlines how the Scholarship will assist the applicant with their studies.

title: JW and BK Elkins Architectural Award
provider: University of Sydney - Sydney School of Architecture Design and Planning
description: The JW and BK Elkins Architectural Award supports honours level students who have completed the Bachelor of Design in Architecture. Established in 1972 by a gift from Mrs. BK Elkins, the scholarship assists students with research or travel during their Honours year in the Bachelor of Design in Architecture (Honours) program.
education_criteria: Completed the Bachelor of Design in Architecture at the University of Sydney and have an unconditional offer of admission for, or be commencing, the Bachelor of Design in Architecture (Honours) degree.
research_criteria: Research proposal required as part of the selection criteria.
achievement_criteria: Academic merit considered in the selection criteria.

title: Margot and Neville Gruzman Award for Urban Design in Architecture
provider: University of Sydney - Sydney School of Architecture Design and Planning
description: The Margot and Neville Gruzman Award for Urban Design in Architecture supports students studying Urban Design at the University of Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning. It is awarded to students in the final year of the Bachelor of Architecture and Environments who have successfully completed the Unit of Study BAEN3001: Design Integration Lab: Urban.

education_criteria.academic_requirements: Final year of Bachelor of Architecture and Environments; successfully completed the Unit of Study BAEN3001: Design Integration Lab: Urban, in the current academic year

personal_criteria.enrollment: Currently enrolled in the final year of Bachelor of Architecture and Environments at the Sydney School of Architecture, Design and Planning

title: Charles Herbert Currey Memorial Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
description: This scholarship supports students enrolled in an undergraduate degree within the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences who intend to commence an exchange program or short-term mobility program, or interstate/international partner university students intending to undertake units within FASS at the University of Sydney. Applicants must demonstrate financial need.

education_criteria.field_of_study: Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
education_criteria.enrollment: Currently enrolled to study in an undergraduate degree within the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences at the University of Sydney or currently enrolled at an interstate university or international partner university

financial_hardship: Identify as an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Island person
Long-term medical condition/disability (including ongoing effects of abuse)
Identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex or queer (LGBTIQ+)

title: Appen Inclusive AI Scholarship in Linguistics
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
description: This scholarship supports undergraduate students within the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences who are majoring in Linguistics at the University of Sydney.

education_criteria.educational_background: Unconditional offer of admission or currently enrolled full-time in an undergraduate degree within the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences at the University of Sydney

personal_criteria.gender: Preference given to female and/or gender-diverse applicants
personal_criteria.personal_background: Preference given to applicants who identify as Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander, or culturally and linguistically diverse

title: The Dr Lena Cansdale Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
description: This scholarship supports students currently enrolled in an undergraduate and/or honours degree in the discipline of Hebrew, Biblical and Jewish Studies who have completed specific units of study in these fields at the University of Sydney.

units_completed: 2 units of study (JCTCXXXX or HBRWXXXX) in one semester
4 units of study (JCTCXXXX or HBRWXXXX) within one year

financial_hardship: Identify as an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Island person

internship.accepted: Must have been accepted into an approved internship

title: Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences Humanitarian Undergraduate Scholarship for Asylum seekers and refugees
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
funding_level: $62,000 p.a. (up to 4 years) + OSHC and SSAF

education_criteria.educational_background: Commencing undergraduate coursework degree

title: International and Global Studies Travelling Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
description: This scholarship supports students in the Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Advanced Studies (International and Global Studies) program who intend to commence an approved exchange overseas.

education_criteria.degree: Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Advanced Studies (International and Global Studies)
education_criteria.academic_requirements: Must be enrolled in the specified degree and have applied for a University of Sydney exchange program.

title: Kerkyasharian and Kayikian Fund for Armenian Studies
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
description: This fund supports honours, master's by research or PhD students or academic affiliates in the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences who are undertaking research in 19th century or earlier Armenian studies at the University of Sydney.
education_criteria: Applicants must be currently enrolled in an Honours, Masters by Research or PhD within the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences at the University of Sydney at the time of scholarship application closing date.
personal_criteria: Applicants must be an academic affiliate employed by the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences.
research_criteria: Applicants must conduct research in 19th century or earlier Armenian Studies. A research project or activity which is likely to contribute towards a recognised research output will be highly regarded.
achievement_criteria: The successful applicant will be awarded the Scholarship on the basis of academic excellence and merit, curriculum vitae, budget summary and justification, and the research project or activity.

title: Lendlease Bradfield Urbanisation Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences
description: The Lendlease Bradfield Urbanisation Scholarship supports undergraduate students in fields related to urbanism including urban development, urban planning, urban design, urban/social policy, project finance, project and/or facilities management, transport logistics and engineering. The scholarship aims to develop future Sydney visionaries who aspire to shape the city's future.

personal_criteria.gender: The University will endeavor to award no less than 50% of the scholarships to female applicants.

experience_criteria.specific_skills: Interest in issues related to urbanism

title: Colin Gladstone Harrison Family Scholarship
provider: University of Sydney - Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences

description: The Garton Scholarship No II for French supports third year Arts and Social Sciences students studying French. Founded in 1898 from a bequest from Thomas Garton of Clapham, London, it is awarded based on academic merit to students with the highest average marks in specific French language units.

title: Aga Khan Foundation International Scholarship
provider: Aga Khan Foundation
description: The Aga Khan Foundation International Scholarship provides scholarships to students from select developing countries who have no other source of financial help for their graduate studies. The scholarships are 50 percent grant and 50 percent loan, supporting students with demonstrated financial need and strong academic credentials.
education_criteria: Students from select developing countries who have no other source of financial help for their graduate studies.

title: American Association of University Women International Fellowships
provider: American Association of University Women
description: The American Association of University Women offers fellowships for non-American women who want to earn a Masters or doctorate in the USA. Priority is given to women who can demonstrate commitment to the advancement of women and girls, and the scholarship may be reapplied every year of the program.
education_criteria: Women who want to earn a Master’s or doctorate in the USA.
personal_criteria: Non-American women; priority is given to those who can demonstrate commitment to the advancement of women and girls.
achievement_criteria: Scholarship may be reapplied every year of the program.

title: Civil Society Leadership Awards
provider: Open Society Foundations
funding_level: Full tuition, living expenses, travel, and other educational costs
description: The Civil Society Leadership Awards offers full scholarships for Masters students from specific countries who are dedicated to fostering social change. The program supports individuals who demonstrate academic and professional excellence and a deep commitment to leading positive social development in their home countries.
education_criteria: Master's students from specific countries

title: Conacyt Scholarships
provider: National Council for Science and Technology (Mexico)
funding_level: Monthly stipend, tuition fees, health insurance, and travel allowance
description: Conacyt provides scholarships for Mexican students pursuing post-graduate studies in institutions abroad. These scholarships support students in science, technology, and other priority fields for Mexico's development, covering tuition fees, monthly stipends, health insurance, and travel allowances.

title: ColFuturo Scholarships
provider: ColFuturo Foundation
description: ColFuturo provides scholarships for Colombian students pursuing post-graduate studies abroad. The program offers a loan-scholarship model where up to 80% of the funding can be converted to a scholarship if students return to Colombia after completing their studies.
education_criteria: Not specified
personal_criteria: Colombian students pursuing post-graduate studies abroad.

description: The Foreign Fulbright Student Program offers scholarships for graduate students from around the world (as well as young professionals and artists) to study in the USA.
